Notably, an artificial port was constructed during the 15th and 16th centuries to address the needs of Barcelona's thriving Mediterranean mercantile center, which had lacked a suitable port during its prosperous period of trade.

In the medieval and Early Modern Age, Barcelona's growing population required a functional port to support its thriving Mediterranean trade, but the city did not have an adequate one. The old port at the base of Montjuïc had become defunct, and the city relied solely on the beach to handle passengers and cargo. As a result, large ships had to rely on smaller boats and manual laborers, known as "bastaixos," to unload their goods. The city did make some urban improvements during this time, such as constructing a sea wall with bastions and creating plazas near the cathedral, but a proper port remained absent until the 15th and 16th centuries when an artificial port was finally built.

During the medieval and Early Modern Age, Barcelona's growing population necessitated a functional port for its Mediterranean trade, but the city lacked an adequate one. Instead, large ships had to unload their goods using smaller boats and manual laborers called "bastaixos." The situation improved in 1438 when the city obtained royal permission to build a port. They started by sinking a ship full of stones as a foundation for a wall connecting the beach to the island of Maians. The wall was reinforced in 1477 and further extended as a breakwater in 1484. The port was later enlarged in the mid-16th century to support Charles I's campaign against Tunisia.

In the mid-16th century, the port was expanded to assist Charles I's military efforts in Tunisia. By the end of the century, the quay had reached 180 meters in length and 12 meters in width. The expansion of the port led to the embankment of the seafront between Pla de Palau and La Rambla, resulting in the urban development of Passeig del Mar, now known as Passeig de Colom.

During the mid-16th century, the port's growth supported Charles I's military endeavors in Tunisia, which ultimately extended the quay to 180 meters in length and 12 meters in width, spurring the urban development of Passeig del Mar (now Passeig de Colom). Concurrently, the water supply and sewage system were upgraded, leading to the establishment of the mestre de les fonts to maintain these improvements. In the 17th century, the city wall was further expanded with the addition of five new gates (Sant Sever, Tallers, Sant Antoni, Sant Pau, and a reconstruction of the 14th century Santa Madrona gate).

In the 16th century, the port's expansion facilitated Charles I's military campaigns in Tunisia, resulting in urban development and upgrades to the water supply and sewage system. This led to the creation of the mestre de les fonts for maintenance. In the 17th century, the city wall expanded with new gates. Later, in the 18th century, the Principality of Catalonia and Barcelona lost much of their autonomy due to Philip V's victory in the War of Succession, which eliminated the Generalitat, the Corts, and the Consell de Cent, replacing them with a military government and reducing the city's jurisdiction to its urban area. During this time, streets were paved, sewers were installed, and drinking water fountains were built. The port also underwent improvement works.

During the 16th to 18th centuries, Barcelona experienced urban development and infrastructure improvements, including water supply and sewage system upgrades, paved streets, and new sewers. The city's demographic grew significantly, and the economy became increasingly industrialized, culminating in the Industrial Revolution. The Bourbon rule introduced military engineering projects, such as the Montjuïc castle and the Citadel (1715-1751), built by demolishing 1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood, displacing 4500 residents without compensation and rerouting the Rec Comtal.

During the 16th to 18th centuries, Barcelona underwent significant urban development, including the construction of the pentagonal, moat-protected Citadel by Jorge Próspero de Verboom. This military project resulted in the demolition of 1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood, displacing 4500 residents without compensation and rerouting the Rec Comtal. The Citadel, completed between 1715-1751, featured an esplanade of 120 meters separating the walls from surrounding buildings.

The Citadel, built between 1715-1751 by Jorge Próspero de Verboom, led to the demolition of 1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood, displacing 4500 residents and altering the Rec Comtal's path. The Citadel's perimeter was transformed into a park after its demolition in the 1868 revolution. Additionally, two new military roads were constructed, one being the Mataró road, which now follows Pere IV street, and the Creu Coberta road, which connects to the Madrid road through Hostafrancs and Sants streets. The Marquis of La Mina initiated the construction of the La Barceloneta neighborhood in 1753.

The La Barceloneta neighborhood was established in 1753 on a peninsula created by reclaiming land from the sea, as planned by engineer Pedro Martín Cermeño. Its design showcases academic baroque urbanism through its grid of orthogonal streets and elongated house blocks.

The Clock Tower, Barcelona's first lighthouse, was constructed in the La Barceloneta neighborhood in 1772, followed by the Llobregat in 1845 and Montjuïc in 1925. In 1771, the Edicto de obreria was approved, a local ordinance that regulated private construction work, including house alignment with street layouts, paving, sewage systems, and house numbering.

The Edicto de obreria, approved in 1771, introduced for the first time the requirement of obtaining a building permit, accompanied by a report and associated fees. Additionally, a height limit for buildings was established in 1797, providing further regulations for private construction works.

In the 18th century, building regulations were introduced, including the requirement of permits, reports, and fees, and a height limit for structures. Simultaneously, the typology of private buildings evolved from medieval "artisan houses" to "multi-family houses" with separate staircases, distinguishing work and living spaces. A significant urban renewal of La Rambla occurred between 1776 and 1778, transforming the medieval torrent into a popular area for theaters and convents.

During the 18th century, urban regulations were implemented, leading to the demolition of the inner wall, realignment of buildings, and creation of a French boulevard-inspired promenade in La Rambla. Although paseos of Sant Joan and Gràcia were planned during this time, they were constructed later, in 1900 and 1820-1827, respectively. This reflects the evolution of urban design and the introduction of new styles in the city's landscape.

In the 18th century, new streets like the one named after Captain General Francisco González de Bassecourt, now known as the New Street of La Rambla (originally constructed as the street of the Count of the Assault, 1778-1789), were built. This occurred as a part of the urban regulations implementation, which resulted in the transformation of La Rambla, reflecting the development of urban design and integration of new styles in the city's layout. The construction of paseos of Sant Joan and Gràcia, although planned during this time, took place later, in 1900 and 1820-1827, respectively.

In the late 18th century, new boulevards such as Paseo Nuevo or Paseo de la Explanada were developed alongside military structures like the Citadel, featuring tree lines and decorative fountains. This was part of the urban regulations implementation, which also led to the establishment of Born and Boqueria markets as the primary food supply sources. In 1752, regulations for marketing measures and coal were introduced. The Citadel's park and its associated amenities were later removed during urbanization works.

During the 19th century, Barcelona experienced an economic revitalization, mainly due to the flourishing textile industry, which consequently triggered a Catalan cultural renaissance. The city's walls were torn down between 1854 and 1859, enabling urban expansion according to the Eixample project designed by Ildefons Cerdà in 1859. Following the 1868 revolution, the Citadel was demolished and its grounds were converted into a public park.

The 1868 revolution led to the demolition of the Citadel, which was replaced by a public park. This period saw a surge in Barcelona's population, largely due to immigration from other parts of Spain, reaching 400,000 inhabitants by the end of the century. Industrially, Barcelona's textile industry took off with the establishment of the Bonaplata Factory in 1832 and the opening of La España Industrial complex in 1849, marking the beginning of the industrial era in the city.

The launch of La España Industrial complex in 1849, owned by the Muntadas brothers, signaled the continued growth of Barcelona's textile industry. However, a crisis in 1861, triggered by cotton shortages from the American Civil War, disrupted this progress. Simultaneously, the metallurgical industry was on the rise, propelled by the emergence of railroads and steam navigation.

The metallurgical industry started to flourish around the same time as the textile industry's growth in Barcelona, mainly due to the advent of railroads and steam navigation. The Nueva Vulcano foundry in La Barceloneta (1836) and La Barcelonesa (1841), a precursor to La Maquinista Terrestre y Marítima (1855), were significant contributors to this growth. Industrialization led to substantial changes in the city's urban planning to accommodate the new demands of the capitalist economy, which needed a high concentration of labor and support services.

Barcelona experienced a significant transformation into modernity during the same period as the metallurgical industry's growth, driven by rural-to-urban population migration, a strong connection between industrial and urban development, and improved infrastructure through an extensive network of roads and railroads. This period also saw the consolidation of municipal ordinances, starting with the Edicto de obrería in 1814, leading to Barcelona's emergence as a metropolitan center dominating its surrounding territory.

During Barcelona's modernization period, the Pregón de policía urbana (Proclamation of Urban Police) was established, outlining 84 articles on urban regulations, building maintenance, and public order. This was later updated in 1839 by the Bando general de buen gobierno (General Good Governance Charter), which further expanded these provisions, now governing aspects like street width in relation to building height, and enhancing public safety measures. These changes contributed to the city's development into a metropolitan center.

The law from January 8, 1845, gave the City Council more authority in urban planning, sanitation, and infrastructure conditioning. This was further built upon in 1856 with the first Municipal Ordinances, which combined, expanded, and organized all urban regulations, including the requirement of interior layout plans for building permits, creating a comprehensive urban code. These developments contributed to the city's growth into a metropolitan center.

The law from 1845 enhanced the City Council's control over urban planning, sanitation, and infrastructure. This was supplemented by the first Municipal Ordinances in 1856, which consolidated, broadened, and systematized all urban regulations. A significant addition was the requirement of interior layout plans for building permits, forming a thorough urban code. However, these ordinances eventually became outdated due to the new Eixample plan, and updated ones were established in 1891 to incorporate the novel features of the expansion and the new connections in the city.

The Municipal Ordinances of 1856 expanded upon the 1845 law by introducing detailed building regulations and increasing plot occupation from 50% to 70%. During this time, significant urban planning actions included the opening of Calle de Fernando (Ferran) and its continuation with Calle Jaime I and Princesa, connecting La Rambla to the Borne. However, these ordinances eventually became outdated and were updated in 1891 to accommodate the Eixample plan and new city connections.

The Pla de Palau expansion started in 1833, making it the city's hub with the Royal Palace, Llotja, and Aduana. The area was enhanced by the construction of Portal de Mar (1844-1848) by Josep Massanès, which was later demolished in 1859 along with the city walls. Massanès also proposed a widening plan in 1838, focusing on the Canaletes triangle, but it remained incomplete.

The Pla de Palau expansion in 1833 turned the area into Barcelona's central hub, accompanied by significant structures like the Royal Palace, Llotja, and Aduana. Josep Massanès contributed to the development by constructing Portal de Mar (1844-1848) and proposing a widening plan in 1838, focusing on the Canaletes triangle, which encompassed Plaça de la Universitat and Plaça Urquinaona, and foreshadowed Plaça de Catalunya. The confiscation of 1836 facilitated urban planning, resulting in the construction or transformation of plots into public spaces, such as La Boqueria and Santa Catalina markets.

The Pla de Palau expansion in 1833 led to the creation of significant structures and public spaces, including La Boqueria and Santa Catalina markets, the Gran Teatro del Liceo (Liceu), and two squares designed by Francesc Daniel Molina: Plaça Reial and Plaça del Duc de Medinaceli. Additionally, new sanitary provisions resulted in the transformation of former parish cemeteries into public squares, such as Santa Maria, del Pi, Sant Josep Oriol, Sant Felip Neri, Sant Just, Sant Pere, and San Jaime (Sant Jaume). This development showcases the urban planning and architectural growth of Barcelona during this period.

The Pla de Palau expansion in 1833 resulted in the establishment of new public spaces and structures, including the creation of Sant Felip Neri, Sant Just, Sant Pere, and San Jaime (Sant Jaume) squares. Among these, Sant Jaume emerged as the city's political center, housing the Barcelona City Council and the Generalitat de Catalunya. Meanwhile, the elimination of parish cemeteries paved the way for constructing a new cemetery, the Cemetery of the East or Poblenou, outside the city. This cemetery was designed in 1773 but mainly built between 1813 and 1819. This development highlights Barcelona's urban and architectural progress during this era.

The expansion of Pla de Palau in 1833 led to the creation of new public squares and structures, with Sant Jaume becoming Barcelona's political center. In 1883, the Southwest or Montjuic cemetery was established, followed by the North or Collserola cemetery in 1969. Additionally, in 1842, the city began using modern gas lighting, with the first illuminated streets being La Rambla, Fernando Street, and Plaza de San Jaime, utilizing town gas produced from dry distillation of black coal. These developments reflect Barcelona's urban and technological advancements during this period.

In 1833, Pla de Palau's expansion resulted in the formation of new public spaces and Sant Jaume emerging as Barcelona's political hub. The Sociedad Catalana para el Alumbrado por Gas was established in 1842, later renamed Catalana de Gas y Electricidad in 1912, and introduced modern gas lighting to the city, starting with La Rambla, Fernando Street, and Plaza de San Jaime. Domestic stoves and heaters began using gas in 1856. The city's growth as a significant metropolitan area's capital was boosted in 1848 with the inauguration of the first railroad line in peninsular Spain, linking Barcelona to Mataró. These advancements highlight Barcelona's urban and technological progress during this time.

The construction of Francia (1854), Sants (1854), and Norte (1862) stations led to Barcelona becoming the hub of a railway network resembling a figure 8, with two intersecting rings. By the 1880s, the city had rail connections to France, Madrid, Zaragoza, Valencia, and other Catalan provincial capitals, further emphasizing its role as a growing metropolitan center and its urban-technological progress.

During the mid-19th century, the construction of Francia, Sants, and Norte stations resulted in Barcelona becoming a railway hub with intersecting rings. Two main railway companies, Ferrocarril del Norte and MZA (Madrid-Zaragoza-Alicante), were established and later merged into RENFE in 1941. Additionally, the city's first fire and police services, the Guardia Urbana de Barcelona, were founded in 1843, initially responsible for public safety and later taking over traffic and urban circulation management by 1938. This reflects Barcelona's growth as a metropolitan center and its urban-technological progress.

In the mid-19th century, Barcelona saw the emergence of private firefighting companies, with the Sociedad de Socorro Mutuo contra Incendios established in 1849. This society was later replaced by the Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona in 1865, which became the city's first public fire department, managed by the City Council. This development represents Barcelona's urban-technological progress and its evolving public services.

In the mid-1800s, Barcelona's first public fire department, the Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona, was formed under the management of the City Council. Antoni Rovira i Trias, an architect, served as its first chief, and the Casa de Comunes Depósitos was its inaugural firehouse, followed by the establishment of several others across the city. This transition reflects Barcelona's urban and technological advancement as well as the development of its public services.

The text describes how Barcelona's public services continued to evolve in the 20th century, with the replacement of animal-drawn vehicles by motor vehicles in 1908 and the professionalization of firefighters in 1913. Additionally, the Diputation of Barcelona played a role in shaping the city's infrastructure by creating new road layouts, such as Sarrià Avenue, the road from Sants to Les Corts, and Garcilaso Street, during the mid-1900s. This information builds upon the previous context by highlighting the ongoing advancements in urban planning and public services in Barcelona.

During the 20th century, Barcelona's port grew in significance as a supplier of raw materials, particularly cotton and coal. To enhance the port's functionality, a new wharf was constructed, and the harbor was dredged, thanks to the efforts of engineer José Rafo, who proposed the project in 1859. Furthermore, the telegraph service was initiated in 1855, with a radial network centered in Madrid, which was later expanded peripherally to include Valencia, Seville, and A Coruña starting in 1920. This information expands on the previous context by emphasizing the advancements in Barcelona's infrastructure and communication systems during this time period.

In the 19th century, Spain established the Dirección General de Correos y Telégrafos, integrating the telegraph service into the postal service. This was done to improve communication, following the expansion of the telegraph network from Madrid to other cities. Additionally, the first public parks were created during this time due to the increasing urbanization and environmental degradation caused by the Industrial Revolution. These parks were funded by public authorities, marking a shift from private to public gardening and landscape architecture. This information continues to highlight the advancements in Barcelona's infrastructure and public services during this period.

During the 19th century, Barcelona's first public garden, the General's Garden, was established in 1816 by Captain General Francisco Javier Castaños, occupying 0.4 hectares between Marqués de la Argentera avenue and the Citadel, until its disappearance in 1877 during the development of the Citadel park. This initiative reflects the growing focus on public spaces due to urbanization and environmental concerns caused by the Industrial Revolution.

In the 19th century, as urbanization and environmental concerns grew in Barcelona due to the Industrial Revolution, several gardens were established along Passeig de Gràcia. The Tívoli Gardens were set up in 1848 between Valencia and Consell de Cent streets, while the Champs Elysées, featuring a garden, a lake, a theater, and an amusement park, opened in 1853 between Aragon and Roussillon streets. However, these gardens were later removed during the Passeig de Gràcia expansion, which was part of the larger Eixample project in Barcelona.

In the 1800s, Barcelona's growth and health concerns due to the Industrial Revolution prompted the establishment of gardens along Passeig de Gràcia, like the Tívoli Gardens and the Champs Elysées. Yet, these green spaces were eventually eliminated during the Eixample project, which expanded Passeig de Gràcia and was initiated after the city walls were demolished. This demolition was crucial because the rising population, from 34,000 at the start of the 1700s to 160,000 in the mid-1800s, had caused high population density, threatening citizens' health. Despite this, the central government resisted the idea of tearing down the city walls due to Barcelona's strategic importance as a fortress.

In the 1800s, as Barcelona's population grew and health concerns emerged due to high density, plans to demolish the city walls to establish gardens along Passeig de Gràcia were met with resistance from the central government, who valued Barcelona's strategic importance as a fortress. However, local advocate Pedro Felipe Monlau led a public outcry, publishing a memoir in 1841 titled "¡Abajo las murallas!" (Down with the walls!), arguing for their removal to prevent diseases and epidemics.

In the mid-1800s, Barcelona's population growth led to health issues due to high density, prompting calls to demolish the city walls and create gardens along Passeig de Gràcia. Local advocate Pedro Felipe Monlau strongly advocated for the walls' removal in his 1841 memoir "¡Abajo las murallas!" to combat diseases and epidemics. After years of resistance from the central government, permission was granted in 1854 for the walls' demolition, allowing the city's territorial expansion. In 1859, the City Council formed a commission to encourage urban expansion projects, leading to a competition. Antoni Rovira i Trias won, but the Ministry of Development interfered, implementing Ildefons Cerdà's project instead. Cerdà had previously produced a topographic plan of the Barcelona plain and a demographic and urbanistic study of the city in 1855.

The Cerdà Plan, proposed in 1859, aimed to address Barcelona's population growth and health issues by expanding the city's territory. This plan introduced a grid-like structure for the city layout, with streets running 20 meters wide in a northwest-southeast direction, intersected by other streets aligned with the coast and the Collserola mountain range. The new design allowed for better urban organization and disease prevention, replacing the previously resisted city walls.

The Cerdà Plan, proposed in 1859, aimed to address Barcelona's growth and health issues by expanding the city with a grid-like structure. The design included 20-meter-wide streets running northwest-southeast, intersecting with streets following the coast and Collserola mountain range. Although Cerdà intended to build on only two sides of each plot, leaving the other sides for gardens, this was not realized, and most buildable land was used. Each building was designed with an octagonal floor plan, featuring chamfers to facilitate circulation. The plan also included the construction of several main avenues, such as Diagonal, Meridiana, Paral·lel, Gran Via, and Passeig de Sant Joan, as well as large squares at their intersections, including Tetuan, Glòries, Espanya, Verdaguer, Letamendi, and Universitat.

The Cerdà Plan, introduced in 1859, had provisions for creating three major avenues in the existing section of Barcelona: two that would link Eixample with the coast (Muntaner and Pau Claris), and a perpendicular one connecting the Citadel with Montjuic (Catedral Avenue). This expansion aimed to improve city connectivity and address growth and health concerns.

The Cerdà Plan, presented in 1859, included the development of new ring roads around the old city, replacing the walls, with specific routes being San Pablo, San Antonio, Universitat, and Sant Pere. This expansion plan was particularly groundbreaking, focusing on allocating green spaces and service areas, considering functional, recreational, and welfare aspects. The buildings in the plan were designed to be 16 meters high, consisting of a ground floor and four stories, and have a depth of 10 to 20 meters.

The Cerdà Plan proposed a sector-based division for Eixample, with sectors measuring 20 x 20 blocks, further divided into districts (10 x 10) and neighborhoods (5 x 5). Each neighborhood was to include social infrastructure such as churches, civic centers, schools, daycare centers, nursing homes, and welfare centers. Districts were to have markets, while sectors would feature parks. Additionally, industrial and administrative facilities were planned, along with suburban slaughterhouses, cemeteries, and hospitals. However, many of these implementations did not materialize due to the City Council's resistance. The plan emphasized integrating green spaces, services, and welfare facilities within the urban fabric.

The Cerdà Plan's sector-based division for Eixample, including social infrastructure and services, faced opposition from the City Council due to their preference for a different plan and real estate speculation. Cerdà's urbanistic theory, as presented in his memoirs and statistical studies, focused on hygienism, among other key points. Unfortunately, many of the proposed provisions did not become reality.

The Cerdà Plan, as outlined in his memoirs and statistical studies, emphasized three main concepts: hygienism, urban orientation, and circulation. Hygienism, inspired by his Monografía estadística de la clase obrera, aimed to address poor living conditions in the old walled city, where life expectancy was significantly lower for the poor. Cerdà proposed improvements in urban orientation, considering factors like climate, and in constructive elements. Additionally, he focused on circulation, seeking to harmonize pedestrian and vehicular traffic on public roads. However, many of these proposed provisions did not come to fruition due to opposition from the City Council.

The Cerdà Plan, as detailed in his memoirs and statistical studies, prioritized three key concepts: hygienism, urban orientation, and circulation. Hygienism, influenced by his Monografía estadística de la clase obrera, aimed to alleviate poor living conditions and lower life expectancy in the old walled city. Urban orientation considerations included climate and constructive elements. Regarding circulation, Cerdà aimed to balance pedestrian and vehicular traffic on public roads, which involved regulating street distribution and adding chamfers to block corners for easier crossing. He also advocated for a multipurpose design, integrating both new and existing spaces into a unified, hygienic, and functional city. However, many of these plans were not realized due to opposition from the City Council.

The Cerdà Plan aimed to create a hygienic and functional city, which included integrating existing and new spaces, prioritizing hygienism, urban orientation, and circulation. However, this part of his project was largely unsuccessful due to opposition and the existence of preexisting suburban layouts and separate urban development projects in neighboring towns.

The Cerdà Plan's objective of integrating new and existing spaces and promoting hygienism, orientation, and circulation faced challenges due to opposition and separate urban development projects in adjacent towns, which included highways, rural roads, railroads, canals, and other land features. Additionally, the new urban grid required the naming of new streets, a task assigned to writer Víctor Balaguer, as there were no traditional names for them.

In the Cerdà Plan, the naming of new streets was assigned to writer Víctor Balaguer, who chose names rooted in Catalonia's history. Many streets were named after territories associated with the Crown of Aragon, institutions like the Catalan Courts and the Generalitat, and notable historical figures from Catalonia. This naming approach aimed to preserve Catalonia's heritage within the new urban grid. However, the plan's goals of integrating spaces and promoting hygienism, orientation, and circulation faced challenges due to opposition and separate urban development projects in neighboring towns, which featured highways, rural roads, railroads, canals, and other land features.

The Cerdà Plan, which aimed to preserve Catalonia's heritage and promote hygienism, orientation, and circulation within the urban grid, named many new streets after historical figures such as Buenaventura Carlos Aribau, Ramón Muntaner, Rafael Casanova, Pau Claris, Roger de Flor, Antoni de Villarroel, Roger de Lauria, Ausiàs March, and the Count of Urgel, as well as significant battles and events like Bailén, Lepanto, El Bruch, and Caspe. However, the plan's goals were challenged by opposition and separate urban development projects in nearby towns, and it mainly focused on expanding the city outside the existing walls, neglecting necessary improvements in the older part of Barcelona.

Following the Cerdà Plan, which primarily focused on expanding Barcelona outside its existing walls and named many streets after historical figures and events, there was a growing need for modernizing the old core of the city. Miquel Garriga i Roca was one of the first to address this need by proposing a comprehensive "interior renovations" project, introducing a joint plan of alignments in 1862, which was the first detailed city plan at a 1/250 scale.

After the Cerdà Plan, Miquel Garriga i Roca initiated an interior renovation project for Barcelona's old city core, emphasizing street realignment. However, due to execution challenges and the lack of expropriation mechanisms, this project stalled. Later, Àngel Baixeras developed a more comprehensive plan in 1878, which included an expropriation bill approved in 1879, leading to further progress in modernizing the city's interior.

Baixeras' plan aimed to extensively renovate Barcelona's old city, focusing on creating three primary pedestrian-friendly thoroughfares, inspired by Cerdà's earlier project. Although approved in 1895, construction didn't start until 1908, resulting in only one road, Vía Laietana, being completed. The project also introduced the tramway as a urban transportation method.

The text discusses the evolution of public transportation in Barcelona, specifically the shift from omnibuses to trams. The omnibus line along La Rambla in 1860 was slow and inefficient. In 1872, rails were installed for tramways, which were lighter and faster, powered by horses. The tram line was expanded from the port to Gracia and then to La Barceloneta. One of the initial tram companies was the English Barcelona Tramways Company Limited. This information is crucial for understanding the development of urban transportation in Barcelona, which is relevant to the context of Baixeras' plan for the city that introduced the tramway as a modern transportation method.

The English Barcelona Tramways Company Limited was one of the first tram lines to be established in Barcelona, starting operations in the late 1800s. During this time, the city saw significant growth in street furniture, with a particular emphasis on aesthetics and functionality, thanks to the leadership of Antoni Rovira i Trias and his successor, Pere Falqués, who headed Buildings and Ornamentation of the City Council. During the late 1800s, the growth of street furniture like lampposts, fountains, benches, and kiosks in Barcelona was facilitated by the booming iron industry, enabling mass production and ensuring durability. In the same year that the English Barcelona Tramways Company Limited and Baixeras' city plan were active, the first interurban telephone transmission between Barcelona and Girona was achieved by Dalmau i Fills. Although the state monopolized the service in 1884, the Sociedad General de Teléfonos de Barcelona was permitted to manage it two years later, which was subsequently taken over by the Compañía Peninsular de Teléfonos. The Spanish dictatorship led by Primo de Rivera nationalized the telephone service in 1925, resulting in the establishment of the Compañía Telefónica Nacional de España, highlighting the continued development of communication infrastructure during Barcelona's urban evolution.

During the late 19th and 20th centuries, the number of telephones in Barcelona significantly increased, starting from 2,479 in 1897 and reaching 850,000 in 2000. Between the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Barcelona experienced a surge in the construction of supply markets, such as Born (1872-1876), Sant Antoni (1872-1884), Hostafrancs (1881), La Barceloneta (1884), Concepción (1887-1888), Llibertat (1888-1893), Clot (1884-1889), Unió (1889), Gràcia (1892), and Sants (1898-1913). The 1888 Universal Exposition was a significant event in Barcelona, occurring between April and December of that year in the Citadel park, previously military property. Its occurrence spurred urban advancements, propelling the city towards modernization and development by enhancing its infrastructure.

The 1888 Universal Exposition drove Barcelona's modernization and development by redesigning the Citadel park, initially a military area. Josep Fontserè led the remodeling project in 1872, creating extensive gardens, a central square, a ring road, a fountain, two lakes, a wooded area, and auxiliary buildings like the Born market, a water reservoir, a slaughterhouse, an iron bridge, and service sheds.

The remodeling of the Citadel park in 1872, led by Josep Fontserè, included the construction of a slaughterhouse, an iron bridge over the railroad lines, and several service sheds. The "Barcelona posa't guapa" campaign (1986-1992), led by Josep Emili Hernández-Cros, focused on refurbishing facades, monuments, and dividing walls as part of Barcelona's preparations for the Games. The celebration of the Games served as an opportunity for strategic urban planning, creating harmony between social and economic agents, and significantly enhancing Barcelona's national and international reputation. Coastal zones were upgraded, pollution was decreased through sewage treatment and underwater reefs, the Llobregat River's path was modified to expand the port, and urban development took place in the Raval neighborhood, resulting in the Rambla del Raval and the transformation of Plaça dels Àngels into a cultural center. Technological advancements and road infrastructure expansion were also implemented during this time.

The "Barcelona posa't guapa" campaign successfully coordinated social and economic agents, enhancing Barcelona's national and international reputation and sparking discussion of a "Barcelona model" for urban reform. In the late 1990s, there was a shift towards more eco-friendly urban planning, focusing on creating environmentally-friendly public spaces and community facilities, as highlighted in the 1998 Sustainable Barcelona Civic Forum.

The Sustainable Barcelona Civic Forum in 1998 established criteria for eco-friendly urban planning. A significant advancement during this time was the promotion of bicycles as a sustainable transportation mode. The first bicycle path was introduced in 1993 on Avinguda Diagonal, and the city has since expanded the space for bicycles. Additionally, the 2007 creation of the municipal bicycle rental company, Bicing, with various docking stations, has further encouraged bicycle use.

In the early 2000s, Barcelona prioritized multi-municipal initiatives, focusing on infrastructure, transport, and environmental restoration. These projects included the development of the port and airport, the AVE high-speed rail route, and the public transportation plan. Furthermore, the city worked on rehabilitating the Llobregat and Besós deltas. Alongside these efforts, the promotion of bicycles as a sustainable transportation mode continued, with the introduction of Bicing, a municipal bicycle rental company, and numerous docking stations across the city.

In the early 2000s, Barcelona prioritized large-scale infrastructure projects, including the enhancement of public transportation. The Infrastructure Master Plan (PDI) outlined the expansion of the Metro system to cover the entire metropolitan area, the reintroduction of the tramway at the ends of Diagonal (Baix Llobregat and Besòs), and the upgrading of the bus network. Additionally, the city focused on rehabilitating the Llobregat and Besós deltas, demonstrating a commitment to environmental restoration and sustainable transportation.

In the 21st century, Barcelona prioritized innovation, design, and sustainability in its urban planning, creating the Urban Strategies Advisory Council in 2000 to aid the City Council in making informed decisions for the city and its vicinity, all while integrating new technologies and a commitment to the environment.

In the 21st century, Barcelona's urban planning prioritized innovation, design, and sustainability, leading to the establishment of the Urban Strategies Advisory Council in 2000. This council, made up of notable figures such as Oriol Bohigas, Dominique Perrault, Richard Rogers, Ramon Folch, Jordi Nadal, and Antoni Marí, aimed to assist the City Council in making informed decisions for the city and its surroundings, with a focus on integrating new technologies and environmental commitment. One of their earliest projects were the transformation of the 22@ district, which involved redeveloping the industrial land in the El Poblenou neighborhood. This area had suffered decline at the end of the 20th century as most companies moved to locations outside the city, prompting the need for revitalization efforts.

In the 21st century, Barcelona's urban planning prioritized innovation, design, and sustainability, leading to the establishment of the Urban Strategies Advisory Council. This council, which included notable figures such as Oriol Bohigas and Dominique Perrault, aimed to help the City Council make informed decisions about the city and its surroundings, with a focus on integrating new technologies and environmental commitment. One of their earliest projects, the transformation of the 22@ district in the El Poblenou neighborhood, prioritized the preservation of the area's existing business fabric, particularly companies focused on new technologies, in alignment with the private sector and the area's daily activities.

The 115-hectare 22@ district in Barcelona's El Poblenou neighborhood underwent significant urban renewal at the start of the 21st century, becoming one of Europe's largest revitalization projects. The area, previously filled with outdated factories, was transformed following the 2004 Universal Forum of Cultures. This revitalization included the regeneration of the Poblenou neighborhood, the creation of the new Diagonal Mar neighborhood, and the development of new parks and leisure spaces for citizens.

The 16-hectare esplanade in the 22@ district, designed by Elías Torres and José Antonio Martínez Lapeña, features a prominent photovoltaic panel and served as a symbol for the 2004 Universal Forum of Cultures. This urban renewal continues the polynuclear grid structure from the 1990s, leading to the development of new urban centers like the Fòrum, 22@, and La Sagrera.

The Plaça de les Glòries Catalanes is undergoing renovation, involving the undergrounding of traffic and reclaiming space for public use. This development is part of the larger urban renewal in the 22@ district. Additionally, transportation in Barcelona has been enhanced with the arrival of the high-speed train, connecting the city to Madrid and Paris. The Mediterranean Corridor, a significant transport route between the Iberian Peninsula and Europe, is in the works. Furthermore, the port and El Prat airport have been expanded to position Barcelona as the primary logistics hub of southern Europe.

The metro system in Barcelona has been updated with extended lines (3 and 5) and the addition of new ones (9, 10, and 11), including automated lines. Also, the bus network underwent a redesign in 2012 to establish a rapid transit system, improving the city's overall transportation.

In 2012, Barcelona's bus network was reorganized to establish a rapid transit system, and plans were made to build a fourth ring road and connect the Baix Llobregat and Besòs streetcars through Avinguda Diagonal. Additionally, the city has installed various pedestrian infrastructure, such as elevators and escalators, in hard-to-reach areas. These improvements have enhanced the metro and bus systems and made the city more accessible for pedestrians.

The neighborhood of El Carmel experienced subsidence in 2005 due to the extension of subway line 5, resulting in the demolition of buildings and relocation of residents. In response, the Generalitat designated El Carmel as an Extraordinary Area of Integral Rehabilitation (AERI), implementing a public works intervention and rehabilitation program for buildings and public facilities. The focus also extended to enhance green spaces in the area. This initiative is in line with Barcelona's broader strategy to upgrading transportation and improving urban accessibility.

The AERI program in El Carmel, following the subsidence in 2005, not only addressed the rehabilitation of buildings and improved public facilities but also enhanced the neighborhood's green spaces. Significant green space projects include the Central Park of Nou Barris (1997-2007) by Carme Fiol and Andreu Arriola, which won the International Urban Landscape Award in 2007; the Diagonal Mar Park (1999-2002) by Enric Miralles and Benedetta Tagliabue, known for its modern design and water features; and the Poblenou Center Park (2008) by Jean Nouvel, which features various thematic areas. These projects contribute to Barcelona's urban upgrade and improved accessibility.

Post-2005, the AERI program in El Carmel focused on not only restoring buildings and improving public facilities but also developing green spaces. Noteworthy projects include the Central Park of Nou Barris (1997-2007) by Carme Fiol and Andreu Arriola, the Diagonal Mar Park (1999-2002) by Enric Miralles and Benedetta Tagliabue, and the Poblenou Center Park (2008) by Jean Nouvel, which has thematic zones and avant-garde design. In 2016, a large dog park opened in Nou Barris, spanning 700 m² with watering facilities and play elements for pets. A fresh wave of urban planning started in 2015, with the drafting of the new Urban Master Plan (PDU) for the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona, set for approval in 2021.

The AERI program in El Carmel, post-2005, expanded its focus to not only restoring buildings and enhancing public facilities but also creating green spaces, as seen in various projects like Central Park of Nou Barris, Diagonal Mar Park, and Poblenou Center Park. A significant addition in 2016 was a large dog park in Nou Barris. In 2015, a new Urban Master Plan (PDU) for the Barcelona metropolitan area began drafting, aiming to complement the 1976 General Metropolitan Plan. The PDU's goals are classifying land, setting building regulations, outlining urban transformation areas, preserving the environment, protecting agricultural and forest land, and ensuring sustainable mobility. The PDU is set for approval in 2021.

In the context of the AERI program's focus on creating green spaces and the development of the PDU, Ramon Torra, manager of the Barcelona Metropolitan Area, describes the PDU's conceptual objectives as creating an ecologically sustainable, economically efficient, and socially cohesive metropolitan urban planning model, with appropriate methods and tools for implementation. In 2016, a pilot project was launched to transform certain city block sets into "superblocks," restricting vehicle traffic and promoting pedestrian movement, cycling, and public transportation, while also providing spaces for leisure and public facilities.

The AERI program's PDU initiative, managed by Ramon Torra, aims to establish an ecologically sound, economically efficient, and socially unified metropolitan urban planning model. A pilot project was introduced in 2016 in Poblenou, covering a group of nine blocks. The project involved modifying vertical and horizontal signs to designate the area, restricting straight-line vehicle traffic (allowing movement only at intersections with a 10 km/h speed limit), and encouraging pedestrian activity, cycling, and public transportation, as well as offering spaces for leisure and public facilities.

The AERI program's PDU initiative, led by Ramon Torra, is working to create an eco-friendly, cost-effective, and integrated urban planning model for metropolitan areas. A trial project started in 2016 in Poblenou, where nine blocks were selected and underwent changes such as altering signs, limiting straight-line vehicle traffic, and promoting walking, cycling, and public transportation. The area between blocks was reserved for public spaces, with architecture students invited to submit ideas. Following this test, the initiative expanded in 2020 to the Eixample district, aiming to establish 42 new green spaces and squares within ten years, with Consell de Cent street being the first area of focus. Four new public spaces will be built along this street, in Rocafort, Borrell, Enric Granados, and Girona.

The AERI program's PDU initiative, under Ramon Torra's leadership, is further developing its eco-friendly, cost-effective urban planning model in the Eixample district. Instead of focusing on blocks like the initial Poblenou project, the initiative will now prioritize pedestrianization and sustainable transportation on one out of every three streets, following a axial layout. This will result in the creation of new plazas at intersecting axes, restricting non-resident private vehicle traffic to a maximum speed of 10 km/h. The plan is backed by a budget of 37.8 million euros, with work expected to begin in 2022.

In 2022, the AERI program's PDU initiative, led by Ramon Torra, will begin implementing eco-friendly, cost-effective urban planning changes in the Eixample district, aligned with the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. These changes, influenced by adjustments made during the COVID-19 pandemic, will emphasize pedestrianization, sustainable transportation, and traffic speed reduction on selected streets, resulting in new plazas and restricted non-resident vehicle access. The project is supported by a budget of 37.8 million euros, with its inception delayed until 2022 due to pandemic-related restrictions, such as the 2020 nationwide confinement in Spain.

In 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic, spaces were reallocated from roads to prioritize pedestrians, creating designated areas for bicycles and pedestrians using colored paint and temporary barriers. Some of these areas were transformed into outdoor seating for nearby bars and restaurants, promoting a safer environment to prevent contagion. This concept would later influence the eco-friendly, cost-effective urban planning changes implemented by the AERI program's PDU initiative in the Eixample district, starting in 2022.

In 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic, temporary urbanism measures were introduced by reallocating road spaces for pedestrians and bicycles, which later became permanent. These changes, initially viewed as ephemeral, were labeled "tactical urbanism" by the Urbanism councilor, Janet Sanz. The temporary areas for bars and restaurants' terraces transformed into permanent structures, regulated by a new ordinance in September 2021, introducing seven new platform models for integrating furniture elements like tables, chairs, and umbrellas in the surrounding area.
